questions.text: Which amino acid donates nitrogen to sodium benzoate when given for urea cycle disorders?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Glycine

 

Explanation:

Sodium benzoate:

  • It reacts with glycine in the liver to form hippuric acid, which is then excreted in the urine, reducing the availability of glycine.
  • Reducing the availability of glycine shifts the equilibrium to favour glycine formation.
  • Ammonia is used to produce glycine, therefore reducing blood ammonia levels.

questions.text: A patient has elevated phenylalanine levels (40 mg/dL), but phenylalanine hydroxylase enzyme levels are normal. Which cofactor deficiency is most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4)

Explanation:

The elevated phenylalanine levels despite normal phenylalanine hydroxylase indicate a deficiency of its cofactor, Tetrahydrobiopterin (BH₄), which renders the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase (PAH) nonfunctional and leads to hyperphenylalaninemia.

Phenylalanine has 2 metabolic fates in the body

Major

  • Phenylalanine gets converted into tyrosine with the help of enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase
  • Deficiency of phenylalanine hydroxylase results in Phenylketonuria.
  • Requires tetrahydrobiopterin (BH4) as a cofactor (Option B)

Minor

Phenylalanine gets converted into Phenylpyruvate by transamination.

Phenylpyruvate can further undergo different pathways:

  • Phenylpyruvate can get reduced to phenyl lactate
  • Phenylpyruvate undergoes oxidative decarboxylation to form phenylacetate
  • Phenylacetate combines with glutamine to form phenylacetylglutamine, which is excreted in urine.

Incorrect Options:

Tetrahydrofolate (Option A) is used in 1-carbon transfers, particularly in nucleotide and amino acid metabolism — not involved in phenylalanine metabolism.

Thiamine (Option C) is a cofactor for enzymes like pyruvate dehydrogenase and α-ketoglutarate dehydrogenase, not related to phenylalanine.

Pyridoxine (Option D) is a cofactor for transamination reactions and neurotransmitter synthesis — not involved in the PAH reaction.

questions.text: Tau protein inclusions are involved in:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Alzheimer’s Disease

Explanation:

  • The fundamental abnormality in Alzheimer’s disease is the accumulation of two proteins (Aβ and tau) in specific brain regions in the form of plaques and tangles.

Morphology of Alzheimer’s disease:

  • Gross: Cortical atrophy (narrowed gyri and widened sulci) is predominant in the frontal, temporal, and parietal lobes.
  • Histology:

Plaques
  • Deposits of Aβ peptides in the neuropil.
  • They are of two types: Diffuse and neuritic (senile).
  • Neuritic plaques contain both Aβ 40 and Aβ 42.
  • Diffuse plaques are predominantly made up of Aβ 42 and seen in trisomy 21 patients.

Tangles
  • Aggregates of the microtubule-binding protein tau.
  • Demonstrated by silver (Bielschowsky) staining.
  • Commonly found in cortical neurons, especially in the entorhinal cortex, and in other sites such as pyramidal cells of the hippocampus, amygdala, basal forebrain, and raphe nuclei.

Hirano bodies
  • Intracellular eosinophilic inclusions are typically found in conditions like Alzheimer's disease and Creutzfeldt–Jakob disease. 

Granulovacuolar degeneration
  • Formation of small, clear vacuoles within the neurons.

 

Plaques

 

Neurofibrillary tangles

 

Hirano bodies

 

Granulovacuolar degeneration

Incorrect Options:

  • Huntington's Disease (Option B) is characterised by toxic gain-of-function of mutant huntingtin protein and neuronal loss in the striatum.
  • Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) (Option C) involves the degeneration of motor neurons, often linked to superoxide dismutase 1 (SOD1) mutations or TDP-43 protein inclusions.
  • CNS Lymphoma (Option D) is a type of brain tumour originating from lymphocytes (B cells) and is unrelated to tau protein.

questions.text: What do chaperones assist in?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C: Protein folding

Chaperones assist other proteins in folding properly during and after synthesis. Folding of over half of mammalian proteins is done by chaperones which can be divided into two types:

  • The hsp70 (70-kDa heat shock protein) family of chaperones mainly binds short sequences of hydrophobic amino acids to shield them from solvents in newly synthesized polypeptides. These are produced in response to stress conditions.
  • Chaperonins are another type of chaperone that form large protein complexes that provide a protective environment for the folding of the newly synthesized protein.

Chaperones provide an opportunity to form appropriate secondary structural elements and their subsequent coalescence into a molten globule, thus preventing aggregation.

Incorrect Options

Option A: Ubiquitination of proteins happens through ubiquitin-activated enzymes.

Option B: Non-enzymatic pathways result in protein modification.

Option D: Proteases assist in protein cleavage.

questions.text: Nitric oxide is derived from:
questions.solution:
Correct option : A

  • Arginine. Nitric oxide (NO) is derived from the amino acid arginine.
  • Nitric oxide is a signaling molecule and a potent vasodilator involved in various physiological processes such as regulation of blood pressure, immune response, and neurotransmission. It is synthesized in the body by the enzyme nitric oxide synthase (NOS), which converts arginine into nitric oxide and citrulline.

Incorrect options :

Option B. Histidine: Histidine is an essential amino acid involved in various biological processes, but it is not directly involved in the synthesis of nitric oxide.

Option C. Glycine: Glycine is an amino acid that plays a crucial role in collagen structure and various other biological functions. However, it is not the precursor for nitric oxide synthesis.

Option D. Aspartate: Aspartate is an amino acid involved in protein synthesis and various metabolic pathways, but it is not directly involved in the synthesis of nitric oxide.

questions.text: The biochemical form of amyloid in hemodialysis-associated amyloidosis is:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Aß2m

Explanation:

  • Hemodialysis-associated amyloidosis is caused by the accumulation of β2-microglobulin (Aβ2M) in tissues, particularly in osteoarticular tissue, the gastrointestinal tract, and the circulatory system.
  • β2-microglobulin is a small protein that accumulates in the blood during long-term hemodialysis, as it is not easily filtered by conventional dialysis membranes.
  • Over time, this leads to the formation of amyloid deposits, which can cause joint pain, stiffness, and other complications in patients undergoing long-term dialysis.

Type of Amyloidosis

Responsible Protein

Organs Affected

Primary (AL)

(Option A ruled out)

Monoclonal light chains

Heart, kidneys, liver, peripheral and autonomic nervous system, GI tract

Senile systemic (ATTR)

(Option D ruled out)

Wild-type transthyretin

Heart

Hereditary (ATTR)

Mutant transthyretin

Heart

Hereditary (AApoA1)

Apolipoprotein A1

Heart, kidneys, liver, peripheral nervous system, skin

Hereditary (AFib)

Mutant fibrinogen A alpha

Kidneys, liver

Hereditary (ALys)

Lysozyme

Kidneys, liver

Isolated atrial (AANF)

Atrial natriuretic factor

Heart

Secondary (AA)

(Option B ruled out)

Serum amyloid A

Kidneys, GI tract, heart

Dialysis-related (Aβ2M)

β2-microglobulin

Osteoarticular tissue, GI tract, circulatory system

Finnish-type (AGel)

Gelsolin

Lattice dystrophy of cornea, corneal neuropathy

questions.text: What do chaperones assist in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Protein folding

Explanation:

  • Chaperones are proteins that assist in the correct folding of other proteins.
  • When a protein is synthesized, it may adopt various three-dimensional structures, and only one of these structures will have biological activity.
  • Chaperones prevent the incorrect folding of proteins and ensure they achieve the correct structure necessary for proper function.
  • They are crucial in the assembly of tertiary and quaternary protein structures.
  • Chaperones, such as heat shock proteins (HSPs), are also produced in response to stress, including heat, toxins, or radiation, and help in maintaining protein integrity under these conditions.
  • Misfolded proteins can lead to diseases, including prion diseases and chaperonopathies.

Incorrect Options:

Ubiquitinization of proteins (Option A): Ubiquitinization refers to the process where a small protein called ubiquitin is attached to other proteins, typically marking them for degradation by the proteasome. This is unrelated to the function of chaperones, which focus on helping proteins fold correctly, not tagging them for destruction.

Protein modification (Option B) involves chemical changes to a protein after its synthesis, such as phosphorylation, glycosylation, or acetylation. While chaperones help proteins fold correctly, they do not directly modify them in terms of adding chemical groups or altering their structure after they are fully folded.

Protein cleavage (Option D) is the process of breaking down proteins into smaller peptides, often by enzymes like proteases. This process is not related to the role of chaperones, which help proteins fold into their correct structures rather than breaking them down or cleaving them into smaller parts.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about the structural organization of proteins?

choices.text: The secondary structure is stabilized by disulfide bonds.
Primary, secondary, and tertiary structures are destroyed by denaturation.
The secondary and tertiary structure depends upon amino acid sequence.

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Tertiary structure is three-dimensional

Explanation:

The tertiary structure represents the overall three-dimensional folding of a single polypeptide chain.

  • It is stabilized by interactions like hydrogen bonds, ionic bonds, hydrophobic interactions, and disulfide bridges.
  • Functionality: The tertiary structure is crucial for the biological activity of the protein, as it determines the placement of active sites, binding sites, and interaction regions.
  • This makes the three-dimensional nature of tertiary structure a key feature in protein organization.

Incorrect Options:

Primary, secondary, and tertiary structures are destroyed by denaturation (Option B): Denaturation affects only the secondary, tertiary, and quaternary structures, leaving the primary structure (amino acid sequence) intact.

The secondary structure is stabilized by disulfide bonds (Option C): The secondary structure (e.g., α-helices and β-sheets) is primarily stabilized by hydrogen bonds between the carbonyl oxygen and amide hydrogen of the polypeptide backbone.

The secondary and tertiary structure depends upon amino acid sequence (Option D): The amino acid sequence (primary structure) dictates how the protein folds into its secondary and tertiary structures, but this does not directly address the structural organization.

questions.text: What is the function of proteasomes?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Protein degradation

Explanation:

Proteasomes are large protein complexes that degrade damaged, misfolded, or unneeded proteins tagged with ubiquitin, maintaining cellular protein quality and regulating various biological processes.

  • Proteasomes are large protein complexes found in cells that are responsible for protein degradation.
  • They play a vital role in maintaining cellular homeostasis by selectively breaking down proteins that are damaged, misfolded, or no longer needed.
  • Proteasomes consist of multiple subunits that work together to recognize and degrade target proteins.
  • The main function of proteasomes is to break down proteins into smaller peptide fragments, which can then be further processed and recycled by the cell.
  • The degradation of proteins by proteasomes is essential for various cellular processes, including the regulation of cell cycle progression, removal of misfolded or damaged proteins, antigen presentation in the immune system and control of protein levels and turnover.

questions.text: Replacing alanine by which amino acid, will increase the UV absorbance of protein at 280nm wavelength?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Tryptophan

Explanation:

Tryptophan has a strong UV absorbance at 280 nm due to its aromatic side chain.

  • Replacing alanine (which has low absorbance at 280 nm) with tryptophan will significantly increase the protein’s UV absorbance at this wavelength.
  • Tryptophan is non polar, hydrophobic and aromatic amino acid.
  • Involved in protein synthesis and neurotransmitter synthesis.

Absorption of UV light at different wavelengths:

  • At 280nm: Aromatic amino acids like tryptophan and phenylalanine
  • At 260nm: Purines and pyrimidines

Incorrect Options:

Leucine (Option A ): Leucine is also a non-aromatic amino acid and does not significantly contribute to UV absorbance at 280nm.

Proline (Option B): Proline is an imino acid and absorbs UV light at 260nm. Therefore, it would not increase the UV absorbance at 280nm wavelength.

Arginine (Option C): Arginine is a positively charged amino acid and does not possess an aromatic ring.It does not contribute significantly to UV absorbance at 280nm.

questions.text: Which of the following methods cannot be used to precipitate proteins?

choices.text: Moving pH away from isoelectric pH

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Moving pH away from isoelectric pH

Explanation:

  • At the isoelectric pH, proteins are least soluble because they have no net charge. This results in minimal repulsion between molecules, causing them to aggregate and precipitate. Hence, high solubility is not a characteristic of the isoelectric pH.

 

Add alcohol and acetone (Option A) Alkaloidal reagents are negatively charged. In an acidic medium, proteins are positively charged. So, by neutralization of charges, negative ion precipitates out.

Using heavy metals and ion (Option B) Neutralisation of charges occur which lead to precipitation of positive ion as heavy metals are positively charged.

Adding trichloroacetic acid (Option D) It is negatively charged. In an acidic medium, proteins are positively charged. So, neutralization of charges occurs and the negative ion is separated.

questions.text: Which of the following is the best method to detect HbA1c?
questions.solution:
Correct Choice: A) Ion exchange chromatography

Explanation:

  • Glycated hemoglobin (HbA1c) is measured by ion exchange chromatography. This method is based on difference in charge. A mixture of charged proteins is analyzed over carboxymethylcellulose paper which is negatively charged. A positively charged resin bed separates negatively charged HbA1c. It has the advantage of separating hemoglobin variants into peaks. Some hemoglobin variants may interfere with results.

 

Electrophoresis (Option B) : It is the movement of biomolecules in the electric field.

  • It depends on charge, size and shape
  • It is used to separate the components of a protein mixture
  • It denatures the protein structure and coats all the protein with a negative charge.

Immunoassay (Option C) measures the presence or concentration of a macromolecule in a solution through the use of an antibody (usually) or an antigen, e.g. ELISA

Affinity chromatography (Option D) is based on affinity between the molecules. A mixture of enzymes and other proteins is analysed wherein the other protein elutes first. It is used to separate enzymes, vitamins, antibodies and hormones.

questions.text: Thermogenin protein is mainly found in:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Mitochondria

Explanation:

Thermogenin is an uncoupling protein (UCP).

  • It is mostly found in the inner mitochondrial membrane in the mitochondria of brown adipose tissue cells.
  • Its main function is to produce heat to maintain the body's temperature.
  • It acts by blocking the formation of ATP and instead, the energy from cellular respiration is used in generating heat.
  • Thermogenin plays a crucial role in thermogenesis and maintains the body temperature.

questions.text: Oxaloacetate is produced from which of the following amino acid?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) Aspartate

Explanation:

  • Aspartate is the amino acid that contributes to the production of oxaloacetate through transamination reactions in the citric acid cycle.

 

Aspartic Acid (Aspartate):

  • Isolation and Characteristics:
    • Aspartic acid (Asp) was first isolated by Kreusler in 1869.
    • It is a non-essential, glucogenic amino acid, meaning it can be synthesized by the body and can be converted to glucose.
  • Transamination and TCA Cycle:
    • Aspartate undergoes transamination to produce oxaloacetate, a key intermediate that initiates the TCA (Krebs) cycle.
    • The enzyme Aspartate Aminotransferase (AST), which requires PLP (pyridoxal phosphate) as a coenzyme, transfers the amino group of aspartate to α-ketoglutarate, forming oxaloacetate and glutamate.
    • Reaction: Aspartate+α-Ketoglutarate→AST/PLPOxaloacetate+Glutamate

Clinical Significance of AST:

    • AST levels are clinically important: Elevated AST is seen in conditions like cardiac ischemia and hepatic diseases (such as liver damage or hepatitis).
  • Malate-Aspartate Shuttle: Transfers cytoplasmic NADH into the mitochondria for oxidation in the electron transport chain, contributing to ATP production.
  • Role in the Urea Cycle: Donating its alpha-amino group to form urea, which is excreted in urine.
  • Glucogenic Pathway:
    • The carbon skeleton of aspartate can also be converted to fumarate, which enters the glucogenic pathway, contributing to glucose synthesis.
    • Reaction:
      Citrulline+Aspartate→Arginine+Fumarate
  • Synthesis of Purines and Pyrimidines:
    • Synthesis of purines: contributing the 1st nitrogen and 6th NH2 group.
    • Pyrimidine synthesis: Its entire structure is incorporated into the pyrimidine ring, contributing the 1st nitrogen and carbons 4, 5, 6.

 

Alanine (Option A) can be involved in the glucose-alanine cycle and can be converted into pyruvate, not oxaloacetate.

Lysine (Option B) is an essential amino acid, and it is not directly involved in the synthesis of oxaloacetate.

Leucine (Option C) is also not directly involved in the synthesis of oxaloacetate. It is primarily involved in protein synthesis and can be catabolized to generate acetyl-CoA, which can then enter the citric acid cycle.

questions.text:
Match the following amino acid with derivatives:

			a.Catecholamines

			d. Melatonin
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) 1-b, 2-a, 3-d, 4-c

 

Explanation:

Amino Acid

questions.text: Ammonia is transported from the brain to the liver in the form of which amino acid?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) Glutamine

Explanation

Glutamine synthetase in astrocytes converts glutamate and ammonia to glutamine, effectively detoxifying ammonia in the brain.

Ammonia Management in Neurons:

Ammonia can be neurotoxic if accumulated.

Glutamine Synthesis:

  • Produced in neurons as a byproduct of amino acid metabolism and neurotransmitter turnover.
  • Ammonia reacts with α-ketoglutarate and NADH to form glutamate, catalyzed by glutamate dehydrogenase.

α-ketoglutarate + NH3​ ​+ NADH → Glutamate + NAD+ + H2​O

  • Glutamate is converted to glutamine by glutamine synthetase, adding another ammonia molecule. Glutamine synthetase is predominantly found in astrocytes.

Glutamate + NH3​ + ATP → Glutamine + ADP + Pi

  • This conversion reduces ammonia toxicity by storing it in a non-toxic form. (Option A ruled out)

 

The fate of glutamine:
Release into the Bloodstream:

  • Glutamine is released into the extracellular space and enters the bloodstream.
  • This transport helps maintain nitrogen balance and prevents ammonia accumulation.

Transport to the Liver:

  • Glutamine carries ammonia from the brain to the liver, where it is deaminated to release ammonia.
  • Ammonia enters the urea cycle in the liver for detoxification.

Importance of Glutamine in Neuronal Health:

  • Acts as a non-toxic ammonia carrier, preventing neurotoxicity.
  • Serves as a precursor for neurotransmitters like GABA, maintaining neurotransmitter balance.


Glycine (Option C): Glycine is involved in various metabolic processes but does not play a role in ammonia transport from the brain to the liver.

questions.text: Which of the following amino acids primarily acts as a buffer in blood due to its ability to accept and donate protons at physiological pH?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Histidine

 

Explanation:

  • Physiological pH & Buffering Role:
    • Histidine has an imidazole side chain with a pKa of ~6.0, which is close to physiological pH (7.4).
    • This allows it to accept or donate protons, making it an effective buffer in blood.
  • Role in Hemoglobin Buffering:
    • Hemoglobin contains histidine residues that help maintain blood pH by binding or releasing H⁺ ions.
    • This is essential in the Bohr effect, which regulates oxygen delivery.

Amino Acids as Buffers

Amino Acid

Buffering Ability

Reason

Histidine

Strong buffer

Imidazole group has pKa ~6.0, close to physiological pH

Arginine

Poor buffer

Guanidinium group has pKa ~12.5, too high to act as a buffer at pH 7.4

Tryptophan

Minimal buffering

Indole group is non-ionizable at physiological pH

Tyrosine

Minimal buffering

Phenol group has pKa ~10.1, too high to be effective
  • Arginine (Option B): Incorrect because its guanidinium group (pKa ~12.5) does not donate or accept protons at physiological pH.
  • Tryptophan (Option C): Incorrect because its indole ring is not significantly ionizable at pH 7.4, so it lacks buffering ability.
  • Tyrosine (Option D): Incorrect because its phenol group (pKa ~10.1) does not participate in blood buffering at physiological pH.

questions.text: A farmer sprayed a chemical in the pool which causes inhibition of complex-III of the electron transport chain. Identify the inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Correct Option: D) Antimycin

Explanation:

  • Antimycin is an inhibitor of complex III (cytochrome b-c1 complex) of the electron transport chain. It interrupts the transfer of electrons from ubiquinol to cytochrome c, thereby inhibiting the flow of electrons through this complex.

 

Inhibitors of the Electron Transport Chain (ETC):

Inhibitor

Target Site

Mechanism

Rotenone (Option A)

Amobarbital

Piericidin A

Complex I

(NADH dehydrogenase)

Blocks electron transfer from Complex I to ubiquinone​

 

TTFA (Thenoyltrifluoroacetone) (Option B)

Carboxin

Complex II

(Succinate dehydrogenase)

Blocks electron transfer from Complex II to ubiquinone​

Malonate

Complex II

Malonate is a competitive inhibitor of Complex II.

Antimycin A (Option D)

BAL

Complex III

Cytochrome bc1 complex

 

Blocks electron transfer from Complex III to Cytochrome C.

Cyanide (CN−) (Option C)

Carbon monoxide (CO)

Hydrogen Sulfide (H2S)

Complex IV

(Cytochrome c Oxidase)

 

Prevents electron transfer from Complex IV to oxygen​

Oligomycin

ATP Synthase (Complex V)

 

 

Blocks the proton channel of ATP synthase, preventing ATP synthesis​

Atractyloside

Adenine Nucleotide Translocase

Blocks ADP/ATP exchange across the mitochondrial membrane​

 

2,4-dinitrophenol (Option D) is an uncoupling agent that disrupts the coupling of electron transport and ATP synthesis in mitochondria. If DNP were added, it would uncouple oxidative phosphorylation from respiration but wouldn’t block respiration entirely.

questions.text: If the RNA sequence is CAAGGU, what is the sequence of the template strand of DNA?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) ACCTTG

Explanation

RNA Sequence given: CAAGGU

  1. RNA-DNA Relationship
    • RNA is transcribed from the template strand of DNA.
    • The template strand is complementary to the RNA sequence.
    • Base-pairing rules:
      • Cytosine (C) ↔ Guanine (G)
      • Adenine (A) ↔ Thymine (T)
      • Uracil (U in RNA) ↔ Adenine (A in DNA)
  2. Step-by-Step Conversion
    • RNA: CAAGGU
    • Template DNA strand (complementary and antiparallel):
      • C ↔ G
      • A ↔ T
      • A ↔ T
      • G ↔ C
      • G ↔ C
      • U ↔ A
  3. Template strand: GTTCCA
  4. However, DNA sequences are conventionally written in the 5' → 3' orientation.
  • Reverse the 3' → 5' sequence to obtain its 5' → 3' orientation
  • That is GTTCCA → ACCTTG.

questions.text: Aromatic ring is seen in which of the following amino acids?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Phenylalanine, tryptophan, tyrosine

Explanation

Classification of amino acids based on the functional group:

 

Amino acids

Examples

Basic amino acids

Arginine, Lysine, Histidine (Option D ruled out)

Acidic amino acids

Aspartic acid, Glutamic acid

OH group-containing amino acids

Serine, Threonine, Tyrosine

SH group-containing amino acids

Cysteine, Methionine (Option C, D ruled out)

NH2 group-containing amino acids

Asparagine, Glutamine

Aromatic amino acids

(Option B)

Phenylalanine, Tyrosine, Tryptophan, Histidine

Aliphatic amino acid

Glycine, Alanine,

Branched chain AA (Valine, Leucine, Isoleucine) (Option A, D ruled out)

Imino acid

Proline

questions.text: Which of the following neurotransmitter is not derived from amino acid?
questions.solution:
Acetylcholine:

  • Origin: Synthesized from choline (an essential nutrient) and acetyl-CoA (from glucose metabolism), using the enzyme choline acetyltransferase.

  • Choline is not an amino acid, and acetyl-CoA is a metabolic intermediate, not amino acid–derived.

  • Acetylcholine is not derived from an amino acid, making it the correct answer.

 

GABA (Gamma-Aminobutyric Acid) (Option A) is a neurotransmitter that is made from the amino acid glutamate through a decarboxylation reaction catalyzed by the enzyme glutamate decarboxylase.

Dopamine (Option C) is a neurotransmitter produced from phenylalanine (amino acid) through decarboxylation.

5 hydroxytryptamine (Option D) Serotonin is a neurotransmitter synthesized from the amino acid tryptophan.

questions.text: DNA sequence is determined by?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: D) PCR

Explanation:

PCR is a technique used to amplify specific DNA sequences, which can then be sequenced using various methods such as Sanger sequencing

Incorrect Options:

  • Flow cytometry(Option A): Used for cell counting and analysis of cell characteristics.
  • FISH (Fluorescence In Situ Hybridization)(Option B): Used to detect and localize the presence of specific DNA sequences on chromosomes.
  • RFLP (Restriction Fragment Length Polymorphism)(Option C): A method used to detect genetic variation based on the length of restriction enzyme-digested DNA fragments.

questions.text: A patient presents with arthritis, and arthroscopy reveals blackening of the joints. Which enzyme deficiency is most likely responsible for this condition?
questions.solution:
Answer: A) Homogentisate oxidase

 

Explanation:

  • Arthritis with joint blackening suggests alkaptonuria, a disorder caused by homogentisate oxidase deficiency, leading to the accumulation of homogentisic acid, which deposits in joints and cartilage.
  • Ochronosis (dark pigmentation): Homogentisic acid polymerizes and stains connective tissues, cartilage, and joints black, seen during arthroscopy.
  • Other features: Black urine (on standing due to oxidation), ochronotic pigmentation in the sclera and ear cartilage.

Alkaptonuria

Feature

Alkaptonuria (Homogentisate Oxidase Deficiency)

Deficient Enzyme

Homogentisate oxidase

Accumulated Metabolite

Homogentisic acid

Key Features

Black urine (on standing), ochronosis (dark connective tissue pigmentation), early-onset arthritis

Affected Areas

Joints, cartilage (ear, sclera, intervertebral discs)

Diagnosis

Urine darkening with alkalization, elevated homogentisic acid in urine

Treatment

Low-protein diet (restricting phenylalanine & tyrosine), vitamin C, symptomatic management
  • Branched-chain alpha-ketoacid dehydrogenase (Option B): Incorrect because its deficiency causes Maple Syrup Urine Disease (MSUD), characterized by neurological symptoms, metabolic acidosis, and sweet-smelling urine, not arthritis.
  • Tyrosinase (Option C): Incorrect because its deficiency leads to albinism, causing hypopigmentation, not joint issues.
  • Fumarase (Option D): Incorrect because its deficiency affects the Krebs cycle, leading to metabolic acidosis, hypotonia, and neurological dysfunction, not ochronosis or arthritis.

questions.text: What do chaperones assist in?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) Protein folding 

Explanation:

Chaperones are essential proteins that aid in the folding of nascent or denatured proteins into their correct three-dimensional conformations.

  • Prevent Misfolding: Chaperones prevent incorrect interactions between amino acid residues during protein synthesis or stress conditions (e.g., heat shock).
  • Assist Refolding: In cases where proteins lose their structure due to stress (like heat shock or chemical damage), chaperones help refold them.

Types of Chaperones:

  • Heat shock proteins (HSPs): Act during stress (e.g., Hsp70, Hsp90).
  • Chaperonins (e.g., GroEL-GroES complex): Create a safe environment for folding inside a barrel-like structure.
  • Energy Dependency: Many chaperones require ATP for their function, especially during binding and release cycles (e.g., Hsp70).

questions.text: A patient who was in excruciating pain all over his body was taken to the hospital. In recent years, he has experienced these incidents frequently. When exercising vigorously, the ache begins. Anemia was detected on blood examination along with elongated RBC as opposed to concave ones. It was determined that he had sickle cell anemia. What substitution takes place in sickle cell anemia?

choices.text: Substitution of valine by glutamic acid at the 6th position
Substitution of glutamic acid by valine at the 6th position
Substitution of valine by glutamic acid at the 5th position
Substitution of glutamic acid by valine at the 5th position

questions.solution:
Correct Option: B) Substitution of valine by glutamic acid at the 6th position

Explanation:

  • In sickle cell anemia, a single-point mutation in the beta-globin gene causes glutamic acid to be substituted with valine at the 6th position of the beta-globin chain

 

Pathophysiology of Sickle cell anemia:

 

HbS Polymerisation: (Option B)

  • A single-nucleotide polymorphism in the β-globin gene results in the substitution of valine for glutamic acid at the sixth position in the β-globin chain.
  • This mutation leads to the formation of mutated hemoglobin (HbS).
  • After deoxygenation, HbS molecules polymerize to form bundles.
  • These polymer bundles cause erythrocytes to adopt a sickle shape and also promote hemolysis of erythrocyte, releasing cell-free Hb into circulation.

​​​​​​​Vaso-occlusion:

  • Sickled erythrocytes impair blood flow and aggregate with neutrophils, platelets, and endothelial cells, causing stasis.
  • Leads to ischemia-reperfusion (I-R) injury.
     

Endothelial Dysfunction:

  • Oxygenated Hb (Fe²⁺) depletes endothelial nitric oxide (NO), forming nitrate (NO₃⁻) and methemoglobin (Fe³⁺).
  • Free radicals are generated by NADPH oxidase, xanthine oxidase (XO), and uncoupled endothelial NO synthase (eNOS) contribute to endothelial damage and dysfunction.
  • Methemoglobin (Fe³⁺) breaks down, releasing cell-free heme, which is a major erythrocyte damage-associated molecular pattern (DAMP).
     

Sterile Inflammation:

  • Cell-free heme or ischemia-reperfusion injury triggers sterile inflammation by:
    • Generating reactive oxygen species (ROS).
    • Activating Toll-like receptor 4 (TLR4).
    • Inducing neutrophil extracellular traps (NETs).
    • Releasing DAMPs, DNA, and other unidentified factors.
  • This activates the inflammasome pathway, releasing IL-1β.
  • Sterile inflammation enhances the adhesiveness of neutrophils, platelets, and endothelial cells.
  • This creates a cycle that promotes further vaso-occlusion.

Option A,C and D is not the pathology of Sickle cell anemia

questions.text: Which amino acid is essential for the conversion of nor-epinephrine to epinephrine among the following options?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Methionine:

  • Methionine: Methionine is an essential amino acid that plays a crucial role in the synthesis of epinephrine. It is converted to S-adenosylmethionine (SAM), which serves as a methyl donor in the conversion of norepinephrine to epinephrine.

Incorrect Options

Option A - Tyrosine: Tyrosine is the precursor for the synthesis of norepinephrine and dopamine, but it is not directly involved in the conversion of norepinephrine to epinephrine.

Option B - Tryptophan: Tryptophan is an essential amino acid that is used in the synthesis of serotonin, melatonin, and niacin, but it is not involved in the conversion of norepinephrine to epinephrine.

Option C - Phenylalanine: Phenylalanine is an essential amino acid that is converted to tyrosine in the body. While tyrosine is involved in the synthesis of norepinephrine and epinephrine, phenylalanine itself is not directly involved in this conversion.

questions.text: What is absent in the urine of a patient who presents with recurrent kidney stones? Below in the microscopic eamination of the patient’s urine sample.
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Cysteine

  •  Cystinuria is an inherited AR disease
  • It is due to a defective amino acid transporter which is responsible for reabsorbing 4 amino acid along the PCT- Cystine, Ornithine, Lysine and Arginine.
  • The image shows cystine in the urine sample in hexagonal shape.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Urine sample contains arginine.

Option B - Given urine sample contains lysine.

Option C - Given urine sample contains cysteine.

questions.text: In which condition is there an excessive excretion of 5-hydroxy indole acetic acid in the urine?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Carcinoid Syndrome

  • In Carcinoid syndrome, there is an excessive synthesis of serotonin or 5-Hydroxytryptamine. This serotonin, after metabolism, excretes 5-hydroxy indole acetic acid into the urine for excretion.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - In Alkaptonuria, urine turns black on exposure to air by the incomplete breakdown of tyrosine and phenylalanine.

Option C - In Albinism, there is defective production of melanin.

Option D - The buildup of phenylalanine in urine is seen in Phenylketonuria.

questions.text: Which of the following should be avoided by a patient with fish odor syndrome?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Choline

  • Choline is recommended to be avoided by patients with fish odor syndrome.
  • In a normal individual, when choline is ingested, it is reduced to TMA by colonic bacteria. The TMA would diffuse passively across cell membranes and enter the enterohepatic circulation. Here, it is removed by the liver, which FMO3 or flavin monooxygenase 3 enzyme normally oxidizes TMA into odorless TMAO. This process of trimethylamine oxidation is defective or impaired in patients with trimethylaminuria.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Biotin does not trigger choline or trimethylamine metabolism. So it has no influence on fish odor syndrome.

Option C - Niacin does not trigger choline or trimethylamine metabolism. So the patient will not have aggravation of fish odor syndrome.

Option D - Pantothenic acid does not trigger choline or trimethylamine metabolism. So the patients with fish odor syndrome can include pantothenic acid in diet.

questions.text: Serotonin is also known as?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - 5 hydroxytryptamine

  • Serotonin is also known as 5 hydroxytryptamine. It is a monoamine neurotransmitter.

Incorrect Options - B, C, and D: These are incorrect

questions.text: Defective fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase enzyme is associated with___
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Type 1 Tyrosinemia

  • Tyrosinemia Type 1 is the most common type of tyrosinemia. It occurs when there is fumarylacetoacetatehydrolase deficiency.
  • It resultsin jaundice, hepatomegaly, hypoglycemia, HCC, and liver cirrhosis.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Type 2 tyrosinemia occurs when there is tyrosine transaminase deficiency.

Option C - Type 3 tyrosinemia(neonatal tyrosinemia) occurs when there is PHPP hydroxylase deficiency and is the rarest of all the types.

Option D - Type 4 tyrosinemia is not known.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with hypertriglyceridemia is considered for niacin therapy. She is a known diabetic managed adequately with sugars well under control. Why should niacin be used cautiously in this patient?

choices.text: It can cause scleroderma, which makes injecting insulin difficult
It can increase the metabolism of oral hypoglycemic drugs

questions.solution:
Correct Option A - It can cause hyperglycemia

  • It can cause hyperglycemia: This option is correct. Niacin, also known as vitamin B3, can cause an increase in blood glucose levels.
  • It has been shown to impair glucose tolerance and increase insulin resistance, which can lead to elevated blood sugar levels. Therefore, niacin should be used cautiously in patients with diabetes to avoid worsening of glycemic control.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - It can cause scleroderma, which makes injecting insulin difficult: This option is incorrect. Niacin is not known to cause scleroderma, which is a chronic connective tissue disorder characterized by thickening and hardening of the skin.

Option C - It can increase the metabolism of oral hypoglycemic drugs: This option is incorrect. Niacin primarily affects glucose metabolism and insulin resistance.

Option D - It can cause hypoglycemia: This option is incorrect. Niacin is not known to cause hypoglycemia. On the contrary, it is more likely to cause hyperglycemia, as mentioned in the correct option.

questions.text: Urea cycle occurs in which part of the cell?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Both

  • The urea cycle involves enzymatic reactions that occur in both the cytoplasm and the mitochondria. The synthesis of urea occurs in the cytoplasm, while the ornithine transcarbamylase reaction, which is an important step in the urea cycle, takes place in the mitochondria. Therefore, option C is the correct answer.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Mitochondria: The urea cycle does involve some enzymatic reactions that occur in the mitochondria, specifically the ornithine transcarbamylase reaction. However, the majority of the urea cycle reactions occur in the cytoplasm. Therefore, option A is not the correct answer.

Option B - Cytoplasm: Many of the enzymatic reactions of the urea cycle take place in the cytoplasm of the cell. These reactions include the synthesis and breakdown of various intermediates involved in the urea cycle.

Option D - None: The urea cycle is a vital biochemical pathway that occurs in the body to remove excess nitrogen in the form of urea. Therefore, option D is not the correct answer.

questions.text: Melanin is synthesized from which of the following?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Tyrosine

  • Melanin is synthesized from the amino acid tyrosine. Tyrosine is converted into a compound called dihydroxyphenylalanine (DOPA) by the enzyme tyrosinase. Further enzymatic reactions and processes involving tyrosinase lead to the production of melanin. Therefore, option A is the correct answer.

Incorrect Option:

Option B - Tryptophan: Tryptophan is primarily used in the synthesis of other compounds such as serotonin and niacin. Therefore, option B is not the correct answer.

Option C - Phenylalanine: Phenylalanine is primarily used in the synthesis of other important compounds in the body, such as tyrosine and various neurotransmitters. Therefore, option C is not the correct answer.

Option D - Threonine: Threonine is an essential amino acid that plays various roles in protein synthesis and metabolism, but it is not directly involved in the synthesis of melanin. Therefore, option D is not the correct answer.

questions.text: Which of the following aids in the process of wound healing?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Hyaluronic acid

  • Hyaluronic acid is a glycosaminoglycan that is naturally present in the extracellular matrix of various tissues. It plays a crucial role in wound healing due to its ability to retain water, provide hydration to the wound bed, and create a favorable environment for cell migration and tissue repair. It also promotes angiogenesis and the production of growth factors involved in healing processes.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Keratan sulfate: Keratan sulfate is a sulfated glycosaminoglycan (GAG) found in various tissues, including the cornea and cartilage. While it plays important roles in tissue organization and function, it is not directly involved in wound healing.

Option B - Dermatan sulfate: Dermatan sulfate is another sulfated GAG present in the skin, blood vessels, and connective tissues. Like keratan sulfate, it contributes to tissue structure and function but is not directly involved in wound healing.

Option D - Chondroitin sulfate: Chondroitin sulfate is another sulfated GAG found in cartilage, tendons, and connective tissues. While it has important structural functions in these tissues, it is not directly involved in wound healing.

questions.text: What is the reason behind the stability of adenosine receptors, which is attributed to the formation of numerous disulfide bonds between?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Cysteine:

  • Adenosine receptors, like many other proteins, can have disulfide bonds formed between cysteine residues. These disulfide bonds contribute to the stability and structure of the receptor.
  • Cysteine contains a thiol group (-SH) that can form a covalent bond with another cysteine residue, resulting in a disulfide bond. These disulfide bonds help maintain the structural integrity of the receptor and are important for its proper function. Therefore, option A is the correct answer.

Incorrect Option:

Option B - Methionine: Methionine is an amino acid that does not participate directly in the formation of disulfide bonds. Therefore, option B is not the correct answer.

Option C - Arginine: Arginine is an amino acid that is positively charged and has a role in protein stability and structure, however, it does not directly participate in the formation of disulfide bonds. Therefore, option C is not the correct answer.

Option D - Alanine: Alanine is a nonpolar, aliphatic amino acid that does not contain a thiol group and is not involved in the formation of disulfide bonds. Therefore, option D is not the correct answer.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the OPD with complains of Mental retardation, mousy odur and hypopigmentation. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Phenylketonuria:

  • Phenylketonuria is an inherited autosomal recessive disorder due to defects in phenylalanine metabolism leading to accumulation of phenyl ketones.
  • Clinical features
    • Mental retardation- Due to phenyl ketones crossing BBB.
    • Mousy odor- Due to accumulation of phenylacetate
    • Hypopigmentation- Due to decreased synthesis of melanin

Incorrect Options:

Options B - Alkaptonuria: Alkaptonuria leads to the accumulation of homogentisic acid, which can cause dark urine, darkening of connective tissues, and joint problems.

Options C - Albinism: Albinism is a genetic condition characterized by a lack of melanin pigment in the skin, hair, and eyes.

Options D - MSUD (Maple Syrup Urine Disease): MSUD is a rare metabolic disorder characterized by the inability to break down certain amino acids, including leucine, isoleucine, and valine. If left untreated, it can lead to severe neurological symptoms.

questions.text: In urea cycle disorders, which of the following can be used to reduce the levels of ammonia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Phenylbutyrate:

  • Phenylbutyrate is a prodrug that is metabolized in the liver to phenylacetate.
  • Phenylacetate binds with glutamine (which carries ammonia) to form phenylacetylglutamine.
  • Phenylacetylglutamine is then excreted in the urine, effectively removing ammonia from the bloodstream.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Glutamate:

  • Glutamate is an amino acid involved in various metabolic processes, including the detoxification of ammonia.
  • It can combine with ammonia to form glutamine, which helps in temporarily storing ammonia.
  • However, in urea cycle disorders, this pathway is not sufficient to handle the excess ammonia production.

Option C - Isoleucine:

  • Isoleucine is one of the essential branched-chain amino acids involved in protein synthesis and energy production.
  • It does not have a direct role in ammonia detoxification or the urea cycle.

Option D - L-carnitine:

  • L-carnitine is sometimes used in metabolic disorders to improve mitochondrial function and support energy metabolism.
  • However, it is not a primary treatment for reducing ammonia levels in urea cycle disorders.

questions.text: An infant presented to the OPD with a history of vomiting and poor feeding. Musty odor is present in the baby’s sweat and urine. Guthrie test was done and it was found to be positive. All are true regarding this disease except:

choices.text: White patch of hair due to tryptophan deficiency

questions.solution:
Correct Option B - White patch of hair due to tryptophan deficiency:

  • White patch of hair due to tryptophan deficiency: This statement is false. A white patch of hair is not associated with PKU. It is commonly seen in another genetic condition called piebaldism, which is characterized by patches of depigmented skin and hair due to the absence of melanocytes in those areas.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Phenylalanine hydroxylase enzyme defect: This statement is true. PKU is caused by a defect in the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase, which is responsible for converting the amino acid phenylalanine into tyrosine.

Option C - Phenylacetate positive in urine: This statement is true. In PKU, due to the accumulation of phenylalanine, it is metabolized through alternative pathways, leading to the production of phenylacetate. Phenylacetate is then excreted in the urine and can be detected through laboratory testing.

Option D - Mental retardation is present: This statement is true. If left untreated, PKU can lead to severe intellectual disability and developmental delays. The accumulation of phenylalanine in the body, especially during the early stages of brain development, can cause damage to the developing brain, resulting in cognitive impairments.

questions.text: Activation of trypsinogen is mainly done by:
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Enteropeptidase:

  • Enteropeptidase, also known as enterokinase, is an enzyme produced by the duodenum. It plays a crucial role in the activation of trypsinogen to trypsin. Once trypsinogen comes into contact with enteropeptidase, it is cleaved to form active trypsin.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Chymotrypsinogen: Chymotrypsinogen is a precursor of chymotrypsin, another pancreatic enzyme, and is not involved in the direct activation of trypsinogen.

Option C - Trypsin: While trypsin is involved in the activation of other pancreatic zymogens, it is not the primary enzyme responsible for the activation of trypsinogen itself.

Option D - Hexokinase: Hexokinase is an enzyme involved in glucose metabolism and is not related to the activation of trypsinogen.

questions.text: The lab technician observes that a urine sample obtained from a 4-year-old male appeared normal initially, but underwent a change in color as depicted in the image after a few hours. Subsequently, the color intensified over the following hours. Which deficiency can potentially lead to this condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Homogentisic acid oxidase:

  • Homogentisic acid (HGA) is a metabolite that is used as the diagnostic substance in the tissues for alkaptonuria. Alkaptonuria is an autosomal recessive disease that occurs rarely.
  • When Homogentisic-acid oxidase is found deficient in the tissue, then normal procedure of phenylalanine metabolism gets blocked and Homogentisic acid (HGA) becomes unable to break. Hence, urine appears as black and dark-stained nappies, and can be seen as the earliest signs of it.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Beta -carotene is a type of carotenoid that is present in carrots, apricots, and sweet potatoes. It is a provitamin and helps the body to make vitamin A. High doses of beta carotene might turn urine bright orange or yellow. 

Option B - Tyrosine aminotransferase deficiency in children causes tyrosine to break incompletely. . Ocular manifestations- Painful corneal erosions and Cutaneous manifestation-: Palmar hyperkeratosis

Option C - Excess vitamin C can change urine colour into dark yellow or orange and vice-versa.

questions.text: Oxaloacetate is produced from which of the following amino acid?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Aspartate:

  • Aspartate is the amino acid that contributes to the production of oxaloacetate through transamination reactions in the citric acid cycle.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Alanine: Alanine can be involved in the glucose-alanine cycle and can be converted into pyruvate, not oxaloacetate.

Option B - Lysine: Lysine is an essential amino acid, and it is not directly involved in the synthesis of oxaloacetate.

Option C - Leucine: Leucine is also not directly involved in the synthesis of oxaloacetate. It is primarily involved in protein synthesis and can be catabolized to generate acetyl-CoA, which can then enter the citric acid cycle.

questions.text: A farmer sprayed a chemical in the pool which causes inhibition of complex-III of the electron transport chain. Identify the inhibitor?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Antimycin:

  • Antimycin is an inhibitor of complex III (cytochrome b-c1 complex) of the electron transport chain. It interrupts the transfer of electrons from ubiquinol to cytochrome c, thereby inhibiting the flow of electrons through this complex.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Rotenone: Rotenone is an inhibitor of complex I of the electron transport chain. It blocks the transfer of electrons from NADH to ubiquinone in the mitochondrial respiratory chain.

Option B - TTFA: TTFA(Thenoyltrifluoroacetone is an inhibitor of complex II of the electron transport chain. 

Option C - Cyanide: Cyanide is an inhibitor of complex IV (cytochrome c oxidase) of the electron transport chain. It prevents the transfer of electrons to oxygen, disrupting the final step of electron transport and therefore blocking the production of ATP.

questions.text: A body builder starts eating raw eggs for protein. He starts to develop fatigue on moderate exercise. The doctor prescribes a vitamin. Which enzyme is deficient in him?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Pyruvate carboxylase:

  • Raw egg whites contain a protein called avidin, which can bind to biotin, a B-vitamin essential for the activity of pyruvate carboxylase. Biotin deficiency can, in turn, affect the function of pyruvate carboxylase, as well as other biotin-dependent enzymes.
  • Pyruvate carboxylase: Pyruvate carboxylase is an enzyme involved in the conversion of pyruvate to oxaloacetate, an important step in gluconeogenesis. Deficiency of pyruvate carboxylase can lead to impaired gluconeogenesis and energy production, which could contribute to fatigue during exercise. Therefore, this is the correct answer.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Glucose 6 phosphate: Deficiency of this enzyme can lead to a condition called glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase deficiency (G6PD deficiency), which is not directly related to the body builder's symptoms of fatigue during exercise.

Option C - PEPCK: PEPCK (Phosphoenolpyruvate carboxykinase)deficiency can affect gluconeogenesis and energy production, but it is not directly related to the body builder's symptoms in this scenario.

Option D - Glycogen phosphorylase: Glycogen phosphorylase deficiency can lead to glycogen storage diseases, but it is not directly related to the body builder's symptoms of fatigue during exercise in this context.

questions.text: Which modification will lead to a change in the biological activity of the hormone given in the picture?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Change in 29-30 in B chain:

  • Insulin undergoes post-translational modification, including the removal of a specific peptide called the C-peptide. A change in the amino acid sequence at positions 29-30 in the B chain could disrupt this processing, leading to altered biological activity.

Incorrect Option:

Option A - Hydrolysis of disulfide bonds: Insulin is a peptide hormone that consists of two polypeptide chains, A and B, connected by disulfide bonds. Hydrolysis of these disulfide bonds would disrupt the structure of insulin, leading to a loss of biological activity.

Option B - Change in 5-6 in A chain: A change in the amino acid sequence at positions 5-6 in the A chain of insulin could potentially affect its structure and binding to insulin receptors. However, the specific impact on biological activity would depend on the nature of the amino acid change.

Option D - Change in 14-16 in A chain: A change in the amino acid sequence at positions 14-16 in the A chain of insulin could potentially affect its structure and binding to insulin receptors. However, the specific impact on biological activity would depend on the nature of the amino acid change.

questions.text: Which of the following would have no effect on the function of the protein product?
questions.solution:
Correct Options A - Glutamine replaced by asparagine

  • Glutamine replaced by asparagine: This is the correct option. Glutamine (Gln) and asparagine (Asn) are both polar, uncharged amino acids with similar properties. Therefore, replacing glutamine with asparagine is a conservative substitution that is unlikely to significantly affect the structure or function of the protein.

Incorrect Option:

Option B - Glutamine replaced by alanine: This is an incorrect option. Alanine (Ala) is a nonpolar, aliphatic amino acid, while glutamine (Gln) is a polar, uncharged amino acid. Substituting glutamine with alanine can introduce changes in the protein's structure and interactions, potentially affecting its function.

Option C - Glutamine replaced by glutamate: This is an incorrect option. Glutamate (Glu) is a negatively charged amino acid, while glutamine (Gln) is a polar, uncharged amino acid. Replacing glutamine with glutamate introduces a charge difference, which can impact the protein's structure, stability, and interactions, potentially altering its function.

Option D - Glutamine replaced by arginine: This is an incorrect option. Arginine (Arg) is a positively charged amino acid, while glutamine (Gln) is a polar, uncharged amino acid. Substituting glutamine with arginine introduces a charge difference, which can significantly impact the protein's structure, stability, and interactions, potentially leading to functional changes.

questions.text: The molecule responsible for the transport of ammonia from the brain to the liver is
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Glutamine:

Glutamine is the molecule responsible for transporting ammonia from the brain to the liver in a process called the glutamine cycle. In the brain, ammonia is converted into glutamine by the enzyme glutamine synthetase. Glutamine is then transported through the bloodstream to the liver, where it is converted back into ammonia by the enzyme glutaminase.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Leucine: Leucine is an essential amino acid involved in protein synthesis and does not play a direct role in transporting ammonia.

Option C - Lysine: Lysine is also an essential amino acid and does not have a specific role in ammonia transport.

Option D - Aspartate: Aspartate is involved in various metabolic processes but is not primarily responsible for transporting ammonia from the brain to the liver.

questions.text: All of the following are derivatives of tryptophan EXCEPT:
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Creatinine:

  • Creatinine is not a derivative of tryptophan. It is a waste product of muscle metabolism and is not synthesized from tryptophan.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Melatonin: Melatonin is a derivative of tryptophan. It is involved in the regulation of the sleep-wake cycle.

Option B - Serotonin: Serotonin, also known as 5-hydroxytryptamine (5-HT), is a neurotransmitter derived from tryptophan. It plays a role in mood regulation and various physiological functions.

Option C - Niacin: Niacin, also known as vitamin B3, is derived from tryptophan. The body can convert tryptophan into niacin, which is essential for various metabolic processes.

questions.text: Vanillyl mandelic acid excreted in the urine in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Pheochromocytoma:

  • Vanillylmandelic acid is a product of epinephrine and norepinephrine (belongs to the group of similar hormones called catecholamines) metabolism excreted in the urine and produced in the liver.
  • Pheochromocytoma, a catecholamine-producing tumor, is a condition in which norepinephrine, epinephrine, and dopamine are released in abnormally high amounts.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Homogentisic acid is deficeint in the urine during alkaptonuria.

Option C - The compound called 5-hydroxy indole acetic acid (5-HIAA) is excreted in the urine in a condition called carcinoid syndrome.

Option D - Ketone is excreted in the urine during a condition known as diabetic ketoacidosis.

questions.text: Maple syrup urine disease is due to a deficiency of:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - α-keto acid dehydrogenase:

  • Maple syrup urine disease (MSUD) is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme α-keto acid dehydrogenase.

Incorrect Options: Options B, C, and D are incorrect.

questions.text: Collagen is rich in which amino acid:
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Glycine

  • Glycine plays a critical role in collagen structure and function. It is the smallest amino acid and has a unique structural property that allows it to fit tightly into the triple helical structure of collagen.
  • Glycine residues are found at every third position in the collagen polypeptide chain, allowing for the close packing of collagen molecules and the formation of stable triple helices.

Incorrect Options :

Option B - Arginine: While arginine is an important amino acid involved in various biological processes, it is not the amino acid that is predominantly present in collagen.

Option C - Phenylalanine: Phenylalanine is an aromatic amino acid, but it is not the primary amino acid found in collagen.

Option D - Tyrosine: Tyrosine is another aromatic amino acid, but it is not the primary amino acid found in collagen.

questions.text: Which of the following releases histamine?
questions.solution:
Correct Option A - Mast cells

  • Mast cells are the primary cells responsible for releasing histamine. They are involved in allergic reactions and immune responses, and the release of histamine from mast cells contributes to the symptoms of allergic conditions.

Incorrect Options:

Option B - Eosinophils: While eosinophils can release certain inflammatory mediators, such as leukotrienes and cytokines, they do not release histamine.

Option C - T-cells: T-cells are a type of white blood cell that plays a crucial role in adaptive immune responses. They help coordinate immune responses and target specific pathogens or infected cells.

Option D - NK cells: NK cells are primarily involved in cell-mediated cytotoxicity and cytokine production. They do not release histamine, which is predominantly released by mast cells.

questions.text: Which of the following deficiencies leads to an elevation of glutamine levels in the bloodstream?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Ornithine transcarbamoylase:

  • Ornithine transcarbamoylase: Deficiency of ornithine transcarbamoylase (OTC) leads to ornithine transcarbamylase deficiency, which is an X-linked disorder affecting the urea cycle. It results in the accumulation of ammonia in the blood and increased levels of glutamine.

Incorrect Options

Option A - Arginosuccinate lyase: Deficiency of arginosuccinate lyase leads to argininosuccinic aciduria, which is characterized by the accumulation of argininosuccinic acid in the blood and urine. It does not directly cause increased glutamine levels.

Option B - Alpha-galactosidase-A: Deficiency of alpha-galactosidase-A leads to Fabry disease, which is a lysosomal storage disorder. It results in the buildup of globotriaosylceramide (GL-3) in various organs, but it does not cause increased glutamine levels.

Option D - Arginase: Deficiency of arginase leads to argininemia, which is a rare autosomal recessive disorder. It causes the accumulation of arginine in the blood and does not directly cause increased glutamine levels.

questions.text: Which substrate of the Krebs cycle is diminished by an excess amount of ammonia?
questions.solution:
Correct Option D - Alpha ketoglutarate

  • Alpha ketoglutarate: Excess ammonia can directly reduce alpha ketoglutarate, a key substrate of the Krebs cycle. Ammonia combines with alpha ketoglutarate to form glutamate in a reaction catalyzed by the enzyme glutamate dehydrogenase. This reaction helps in the removal of excess ammonia through the urea cycle.

Incorrect Options

Option A - Malate: Excess ammonia does not directly reduce malate, a substrate of the Krebs cycle. Malate is formed in the Krebs cycle and can be converted back to oxaloacetate.

Option B - Oxaloacetate: Excess ammonia does not directly reduce oxaloacetate, another substrate of the Krebs cycle. Oxaloacetate is an intermediate compound in the cycle and can be converted to malate or used for gluconeogenesis.

Option C - Fumarate: Excess ammonia does not directly reduce fumarate, which is also an intermediate compound in the Krebs cycle. Fumarate is produced from the conversion of malate and is further converted to succinate.

questions.text: What is the shared precursor amino acid for urea, creatinine, and nitric oxide?
questions.solution:
Correct Option B - Arginine:

  • Urea: Arginine is a precursor for urea synthesis in the urea cycle. It undergoes a series of enzymatic reactions, eventually leading to the production of urea.
  • Creatinine: Creatinine is derived from creatine phosphate, which is synthesized from arginine in a two-step process. Creatine is first converted to creatine phosphate in the presence of arginine and glycine, and then creatine phosphate spontaneously converts to creatinine.
  • Nitric oxide: Nitric oxide (NO) is synthesized from arginine by the enzyme nitric oxide synthase (NOS). Arginine serves as the substrate for NOS, which catalyzes the production of NO.

Incorrect Options:

Option A - Glycine: Glycine is not a precursor for urea, creatinine, or nitric oxide synthesis.

Option C - Aspartate: Aspartate is involved in the urea cycle as a substrate, but it is not the precursor amino acid for urea, creatinine, or nitric oxide.

Option D - Alanine: Alanine is not directly involved in the synthesis of urea, creatinine, or nitric oxide.

questions.text: Which of the following is responsible for the negative charge in fibrinopeptide A?
questions.solution:
Correct Option C - Aspartate and glutamate

  • Glutamate and aspartate are acidic amino acids that are responsible for negative charge in fibrinopeptide A .

Incorrect Options

Option A - In the case of glutamate and valine, though glutamate is acidic and negatively charged, valine is a nonpolar amino acid and is neutral in charge. So, this pair cannot be responsible for the negative charge in fibrinopeptide A.

Option B - In the case of histidine and lysine, both amino acids are basic and bear a positive charge. Also, they are not part of fibrinopeptide A, proving the b option incorrect.

Option D - In the case of serine and threonine, though serine is part one of the amino acids from which Fibrinopeptide A polypeptide is made, it’s neutral. And Fibrinopeptide A molecule does not contain threonine as its part, proving it an incorrect choice.
